topic.name: Ancient Near Eastern Background (OT)
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Ancient Near Eastern Background (OT) in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify that the Bible covers a very, very long time.
Identify God as the one who spoke the world into being.
Name the sun and moon as lights God made, not gods to worship.
Identify that the Old Testament was written in Hebrew.
Name 'Shalom' as a Hebrew word for peace.
Identify rules as things that keep us safe.
Name the Ten Commandments as God's special rules.
Identify Egypt as the land of Pyramids and the Nile River.
Name Abraham's first home as the city of Ur.
Recall that Jesus came at exactly the right time.
Recall that other people believed scary stories about monsters making the world.
Recall that Jesus spoke a language called Aramaic.
Observe what Hebrew letters look like (reading right to left).
Recall that kings in Bible times made rules on big stones.
Observe that God's laws are fair and good.
Recall that people in Bible times wrote on clay and stone.
Observe pictures of ancient ziggurats (tall towers).
Order the pictures of Adam, Noah, Moses, and Jesus.
Use a timeline string to see who lived first.
Summarize the main eras: Creation, Patriarchs, Exodus, Kings, Exile.
Explain the difference between BC (Before Christ) and AD (Anno Domini).
Explain the debate between the Early Date and Late Date of the Exodus.
Defend the historicity of the biblical timeline against minimalism.
Produce a study on the significance of the '400 Silent Years'.
Express thanks that our God is good and loving.
Summarize the difference between believing in one God (Monotheism) and many gods (Polytheism).
Explain that Genesis says humans are special rulers, not slaves to gods.
Categorize the stars as creation, not controllers of our fate.
Explain the concept of the 'Cosmic Temple' in ancient thought.
Defend the transcendence and immanence of God against pantheism.
Produce an essay on how the biblical worldview dignifies humanity.
Summarize how we got our English Bible from the original languages.
Explain that some parts of Daniel were written in Aramaic.
Explain why the Jews translated the OT into Greek (the Septuagint).
Defend the preservation of the biblical text through history.
Summarize the idea of 'eye for an eye' (fairness, not revenge).
Explain what a 'treaty' is (an agreement between a king and people).
Explain how the Mosaic law protected servants and women uniquely in the ancient world.
Perform research on the Hittite treaties of the 2nd millennium BC.
Summarize the geography of the Fertile Crescent.
Explain how the Nile River helped Egypt grow food.
Locate Babylon, Assyria, and Egypt on a Bible map.
Explain the significance of the 'cradle of civilization' for biblical history.
Defend the historical reliability of the biblical account amidst ANE records.
Recognize that translation involves choosing the best words.
Compare the time of David (1000 BC) to the time of the Exile (586 BC).
Calculate how many years ago Jesus lived.
Analyze the genealogies in Genesis (understanding 'begat').
Interpret the 480 years mentioned in 1 Kings 6:1.
Connect biblical events to fixed dates in history (e.g., Battle of Carchemish).
Compare the peace of the Garden of Eden with the violence of other creation myths.
Analyze the Enuma Elish and its contrast with Genesis 1.
Interpret Genesis 1 as a 'polemic' (argument) against pagan worldviews.
Connect the biblical view of nature (demythologized) to the rise of science.
Compare the look of English letters to Hebrew letters.
Analyze the importance of the Dead Sea Scrolls.
Connect the Ugaritic language to understanding difficult Hebrew poetry.
Compare the harsh laws of Hammurabi with the laws of Moses.
Apply the idea that God is our King and we are His people.
Analyze the suzerain-vassal treaty structure in Deuteronomy.
Interpret the difference between apodictic (absolute) and casuistic (case) law.
Connect the blessings and curses of the Law to ancient treaty formats.
Compare the life of an Israelite shepherd with an Egyptian city dweller.
Analyze the geopolitical struggle between the empires of the North (Assyria/Babylon) and the South (Egypt).
Interpret the cultural significance of the Code of Hammurabi.
Connect the plagues of Egypt to specific Egyptian false gods.
Evaluate the challenges of biblical chronology (Masoretic vs. Septuagint numbers).
Evaluate the 'chaos monster' motif (Leviathan/Rahab) in Scripture vs. ANE mythology.
Evaluate the 'lex talionis' (law of retaliation) as a limit on vengeance.
Evaluate the archaeological evidence for Israel's presence in Egypt.
Construct a basic word study using a concordance.
Interpret the difference between a 'word-for-word' and 'thought-for-thought' translation.
Construct a synchronized timeline of Hebrew Kings and Assyrian/Babylonian rulers.
Construct a worldview comparison: Ancient Paganism vs. Biblical Theism vs. Modern Materialism.
Synthesize the impact of Aramaic as the 'lingua franca' of the ancient Near East.
Construct a comparison of ANE law codes and the Torah regarding the value of human life.
Synthesize the uniqueness of Israel's law being grounded in the character of Yahweh.
Construct a profile of the Assyrian war machine and its impact on Israel.
Synthesize the rise and fall of ANE empires with the prophecies of Daniel.
Evaluate how knowing original languages enriches theology (e.g., 'Chesed' - lovingkindness).
